questions.text: While attempting to remove a fish bone lodged in the pyriform fossa, injury to which of the following nerves is most likely? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal laryngeal

 

The pyriform fossa is part of the hypopharynx (laryngopharynx) and is located lateral to the arytenoid cartilages. 

 

The key anatomical landmark for understanding nerve supply in this region is the level of the vocal cords. The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve supplies the mucosa above the level of the vocal cords, while the recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies the mucosa below this level. Since the pyriform fossa is positioned lateral to the arytenoids and at the level of or slightly above the vocal cords, it receives sensory innervation from the internal laryngeal nerve.

 


 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Vagus: While the internal laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve, the specific nerve innervating the pyriform fossa is the internal laryngeal branch, making this answer too general.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal: This nerve supplies structures below the level of the vocal cords, including the post-cricoid area and lower portions of the hypopharynx, but not the pyriform fossa.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal: This nerve primarily supplies the oropharynx, posterior third of the tongue, and tonsillar region, not the hypopharyngeal structures like the pyriform fossa.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The pyriform fossa receives sensory innervation from the internal laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal laryngeal nerve

 

Cough reflex is a protective mechanism of the larynx to expel foreign irritants in order to keep airway clear. Afferent of this reflex is through internal laryngeal nerve, which gives sensory supply to mucosa above vocal cords. Irritant substances like alcohol affects the nervous system causing inhibition of cough reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Primarily involved in the sensation and taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue, not directly involved in the cough reflex at the larynx.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: Mainly supplies the cricothyroid muscle with motor fibers and does not have a sensory role in the cough reflex.

 

Option D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid and provides sensory innervation to the mucosa below the vocal cords; thus, it plays a role in the cough reflex but primarily for the lower part of the larynx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to or inhibition of the internal laryngeal nerve can significantly impair the cough reflex by reducing the sensory input required to detect irritants above the vocal cords, emphasizing its pivotal role in this protective reflex.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 337

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient arrives at the OPD with a concern about her ability to perceive speech sounds while struggling to comprehend the actual words being spoken. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results show discrepancies, as the PTA is relatively within the normal range. However, her mid-latency and cortical responses are both non-existent. What probable diagnosis can be inferred from these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy

 

If a child arrives with concerns about not being able to comprehend words, and their BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) results are abnormal while their PTA (Pure Tone Audiometry) results are normal, this could indicate the presence of auditory neuropathy.

 

Auditory neuropathy is a neurologic disorder of CN VIII. Audiometric tests, e.g. SNHL for pure tones, impaired speech discrimination score, absent or abnormal auditory brainstem response, show a retrocochlear type of lesion but OAEs are normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Michel aplasia also known as complete labyrinthine aplasia, is the most severe congenital inner ear malformation, characterized by complete absence of inner ear structures. This condition would present with profound hearing loss detected on PTA, not normal PTA results.

 

Option C. Malingering: Intentional falsification of hearing loss would likely be exposed by objective tests like BERA, which would not show the abnormal results observed in this case.

 

Option D. Cochlear otosclerosis shows Carhart’s notch (dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction) on PTA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auditory neuropathy should be suspected in patients who present with normal hearing sensitivity on pure tone audiometry but show significant difficulties with speech comprehension and abnormal brainstem evoked response audiometry results.

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid abscess

 

  • The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of a parotid abscess.
  • It is suppuration of the parotid space. Deep cervical fascia splits into two layers, superficial and deep, to enclose the parotid gland and its associated structures. Parotid space lies deep to its superficial layer.
  • Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases and debilitated patients, with stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause.
  • Most common organism- Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Presents with unilateral swelling associated with redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present.
  • Investigations -
    • Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan – to know extent of abscess
    • Aspiration of abscess for culture and sensitivity to isolate causative organism
  • Treatment -
    • Surgical drainage of the abscess is done via a preauricular incision along with IV antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: is a complication of mastoiditis which presents as swelling in upper part of neck when pus breaks inferiorly, through the tip of the mastoid

 

Option C. Upper cervical lymphadenopathy: occurs in the neck region following infection in the area drained by these structures.

 

Option D. Osteoma of the mandible: characterized by a benign, slow-growing tumor on the mandible, which is usually painless and asymptomatic, not presenting with tenderness and acute symptoms like an abscess.

 

Educational Objective:


Diagnosing and treating a parotid abscess promptly is crucial to prevent further complications such as the spread of infection. The characteristic presentation of swelling, tenderness, and systemic signs in a specific location aids in differential diagnosis from other potential conditions affecting the neck and jaw area.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 297

questions.text: Otosclerosis most commonly begins at which of the following locations? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fissula Ante-fenestram

 

Explanation:

 

Otosclerosis most commonly begins at the fissula ante fenestram. This is a small depression located in front of the oval window in the otic capsule. This is the initial site where the abnormal bone remodeling process begins, which eventually extends to involve the stapes footplate causing its fixation and conductive hearing loss. The fissula ante fenestrum is considered the classic starting point for otosclerotic lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fossula Post-fenestram: While otosclerotic foci can develop in various locations within the otic capsule, the fossula post-fenestram (behind the oval window) is not the most common initial site. Otosclerosis predominantly begins at the area anterior to the oval window (fissula ante fenestram).

 

Option C. Footplate of Stapes: Although the stapes footplate is eventually involved in otosclerosis, leading to the characteristic stapes fixation and conductive hearing loss, it is not typically the primary site where the disease process begins. The disease usually starts in the fissula ante fenestram and then extends to involve the footplate.

 

Option D. Oval Window: The oval window itself is not the initial site of otosclerotic change. The oval window is the opening between the middle and inner ear into which the stapes footplate fits. Otosclerosis begins in the bone adjacent to this structure (in the fissula ante fenestram) and then extends to involve the stapes footplate and oval window area.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Otosclerosis characteristically begins in the fissula ante fenestram (anterior to the oval window) before extending to involve the stapes footplate, causing the fixation that leads to conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: For newborn hearing screening purpose, which test is most commonly used? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) OAE

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) is the most commonly used test for newborn hearing screening. OAE testing is a simple, quick, and non-invasive method that measures sounds (emissions) produced by the inner ear (cochlea) in response to an auditory stimulus. This test is highly effective for detecting hearing loss in newborns and can be performed shortly after birth. If the OAE test results are normal, no further testing is needed. However, if the OAE test is abnormal, further evaluation with Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is recommended after three months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BERA: Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) is used if OAE results are abnormal. It is more comprehensive but not used as the initial screening test due to its complexity and requirement for specialized equipment.

 

Option C. PTA: Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) is not suitable for newborns as it requires behavioral responses to sound, which cannot be reliably obtained from newborns.

 

Option D. Impedance: Impedance audiometry measures the function of the middle ear but is not used for initial newborn hearing screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) testing is the standard and most commonly used initial screening method for detecting hearing loss in newborns due to its simplicity, quick results, and effectiveness.

questions.text: Which condition is associated with the appearance of Brown sign? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glomus tumor

 

Explanation: 

 

The Brown sign (also called pulsation sign) is specifically associated with glomus tumors. This sign is characterized by pulsation of the mass in the middle ear that can be observed through the tympanic membrane. Glomus tumors (paragangliomas) are highly vascular neoplasms that originate from paraganglionic tissue. Their vascularity results in visible pulsations that characterize the Brown sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere's disease: This is characterized by endolymphatic hydrops with symptoms of episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is not associated with any visible pulsating mass or the Brown sign as it affects the inner ear rather than producing a middle ear mass.

 

Option C. Acoustic neuroma: This is a benign tumor of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) that typically presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes vertigo. It develops in the internal auditory canal or cerebellopontine angle, not in the middle ear, and does not present with visible pulsations or Brown sign.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: This is characterized by abnormal bone formation around the stapes footplate, leading to progressive conductive hearing loss. It does not present with a visible pulsating mass or Brown sign. The otoscopic findings in otosclerosis are typically normal or may show a pinkish hue through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Brown sign (pulsation sign) refers to visible pulsations of a middle ear mass seen through the tympanic membrane and is pathognomonic for glomus tumors due to their highly vascular nature.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions are potential causes of stridor in a newborn? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Laryngomalacia
  2. Subglottic stenosis
  3. Papilloma
  4. Hemorrhagic polyp
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 2

 

Stridor in newborns is primarily caused by congenital airway abnormalities that compromise the airway from birth. 

 

1. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital anomaly of the larynx and the most common cause of stridor in infants. It presents with inspiratory stridor due to excessively flaccid supraglottis that collapses during inspiration. 

 

2. Subglottic stenosis: Subglottic stenosis also causes stridor in newborns because the subglottis is the narrowest part of the airway in children, and any further narrowing causes significant airway compromise, resulting in biphasic stridor.



Other Options:

 

3. Papilloma: This typically presents in children aged 3-5 years, not in newborns. Although caused by HPV infection acquired during birth through the vaginal canal, the clinical presentation occurs years later, not in the neonatal period.

 

4. Hemorrhagic polyp: This appears on the vocal cord surface and primarily causes hoarseness of voice rather than stridor. It does not cause sufficient airway obstruction to produce stridor in newborns.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Laryngomalacia and subglottic stenosis are the primary causes of stridor in newborns.

questions.text: Which staging is related to JNA? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radkowski

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that typically affects adolescent males. The staging system specifically related to JNA is the Radkowski staging system. This system helps to classify the extent of the tumor based on its location and spread:

 

  • Stage I: Tumor confined to the nasopharynx, nasal cavity, and may involve the paranasal sinuses.
  • Stage II: Tumor extends into the pterygopalatine fossa.
  • Stage III: Tumor invades the infratemporal fossa.
  • Stage IV: Tumor extends to the intracranial space, including the foramen magnum.

 

The Radkowski staging system helps in determining the surgical approach and prognosis for patients with JNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TNM: The TNM staging system is used for various carcinomas, especially solid tumors like those in breast cancer, lung cancer, etc. It stands for Tumor, Node, Metastasis.

 

Option B. Ann Arbor: The Ann Arbor staging system is used for lymphomas, particularly Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas.

 

Option D. Dukes: The Dukes staging system is used for colorectal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Radkowski staging system is specifically used for staging Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), assessing its extent and guiding treatment options.

questions.text: Under which of the following, Rhinosporidium seeberi is classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aquatic Protistan protozoa

 

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS

 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)
  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.
  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas
  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.
  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness
  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)
  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Although previously considered a fungus, current classifications based on molecular analysis place Rhinosporidium seeberi under protozoa.

 

Option B: Viruses are infectious agents that replicate inside the living cells of organisms which is not a characteristic of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Option D: Bacteria are single-celled microorganisms with simple internal structures, quite distinct from the complex life cycle and morphology of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidium seeberi, responsible for rhinosporidiosis, is classified as an aquatic Protistan protozoa, not a fungus, highlighting the importance of accurate organism classification in understanding transmission and management of infections.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with throat pain, fever, and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve

 

The Jacobson nerve / tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Jacobson nerve = tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal (IX cranial nerve) – supplies middle ear mucosa. Referred otalgia from tonsillitis / pharyngitis / Cancers of base of tongue is due to this nerve common innervation (ear & pharynx).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Greater Auricular Nerve: Arises from the cervical plexus (C2, C3) and primarily innervates the skin over the parotid gland and mastoid region, not typically involved in referred ear pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option C. Auriculotemporal Nerve: A branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), which innervates the anterior auricle and external acoustic meatus, contributing to sensations in these areas but not typically involved in referred pain from tonsillitis.

 

Option D. Auricular Branch of Vagus Nerve: Also known as Arnold’s nerve, supplies the concha and part of the external auditory canal and could potentially contribute to referred otalgia, but not primarily responsible in cases of tonsillitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

 

  • A left hypoactive labyrinth is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features.
  • Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component.
  • The fast component denotes the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, and trauma to the labyrinth cause nystagmus to the healthy side.
  • Serous labyrinthitis (irritative lesion) leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: Characterized by positional vertigo and typically vertical nystagmus, related to the posterior semicircular canal.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Also known as anterior canal BPPV, would cause primarily vertically oriented nystagmus, not horizontal.

 

Option C. Right hypoactive labyrinth: Would produce nystagmus with the slow component towards the right and the fast component towards the left, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the aquatic organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects mucous membranes, especially in the nasal passages but also the eyes, ears, and occasionally other areas. Patients typically present with polypoidal masses in the nasal area that can cause bleeding, nasal obstruction, and respiratory difficulty. It is commonly associated with exposure to stagnant water.

Histopathology: Characteristic findings include large, thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores, as observed in the provided histopathological image.

Other Options: 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly appears on sun-exposed areas but can occasionally occur near the nasal region. It typically presents as a nodular lesion with a pearly edge and may have telangiectasias but lacks the distinct histopathology of sporangia with endospores.

Histopathology: Microscopically, it shows nests of basaloid cells with palisading nuclei at the periphery.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the respiratory tract. It leads to the formation of hard, sclerotic nodules and masses mainly in the nasal passages.

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells, which are large foam cells containing the bacteria, and a background of chronic inflammatory cells.

Option D. Lupus Vulgaris

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting typically on the skin with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate over time. It rarely affects the nasal area directly unless there is disseminated cutaneous involvement.

Histopathology: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis typical of tuberculosis.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical scenario and histology image showing Verocay bodies are suggestive of Schwannoma /Acoustic neuroma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibroma is a benign tumor that develops along nerve cells. Histology image shows wreath like multinucleated giant cells.

 

 

Option B. Leiomyoma on histology shows well-differentiated, regular, spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with hyalinization.

 

 

Option D. Rhabdomyoma on microscopy shows enlarged myocytes with abundant glycogen. Post-processing, glycogen content gets reduced and look like thin strands.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Allergic rhinitis is a condition characterized by symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose, and itchy eyes. These symptoms can lead to several physical signs due to chronic inflammation and repetitive actions like rubbing the nose and eyes. However we do not see Otto Veraguth folds in Allergic Rhinitis.

 Also known as Veraguth folds, these are small creases on the upper eyelid and are not related to allergic rhinitis. They are typically associated with individuals suffering from depression, not allergic conditions.

Other Options:

Option A. Allergic Shiners: Commonly seen in allergic rhinitis due to venous congestion under the eyes.

Option B. Allergic Salute: A habitual action in allergic rhinitis leading to a nasal crease.

Option D. Dennis Morgan Lines: Found in chronic allergic conditions due to persistent inflammation and edema, including allergic rhinitis.

Educational Objective: 

Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper airway examination

 

The image shows a tracheostomy tube, which is not used for upper airway examination.

 

Tracheostomy:

 

  • It is a procedure where alternative airway is established when normal airway is compromised.
  • An opening is made on the anterior wall of trachea and a tube is inserted, through which air exchange occurs between lungs and outside.
  • It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50%.
  • Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings.
  • High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx.
  • In emergency tracheostomy, vertical incision is taken but in elective cases, horizontal incision is taken.
  • It is generally a temporary procedure till the pathology in the upper bypassed airway clears.
  • In some cases, like cancer larynx where laryngectomy was done, permanent tracheostomy is done.
  • Removal of tracheostomy tube is called decannulation.
  • Different types of tracheostomy tubes – PVC, Metallic (Chevalier-Jackson), etc.
  • Complications of tracheostomy → surgical emphysema, hemorrhage, Apnea due to CO2 washout, Pneumothorax, Tube displacement, Tube blockage, Tracheomalacia, Subglottic stenosis

 

Other Options:

 

Primary Uses of a Tracheostomy Tube Include:

 

Option A. Airway Toileting: Facilitates the removal of secretions from the airways.

 

Option C. Acute Nasopharyngeal Obstruction: Provides an airway bypass in cases of blockage in the upper airway.

 

Option D. Prolonged Mechanical Ventilation: Offers a secure, stable method for long-term ventilation support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy tubes are not used for examining the upper airway as they do not provide access or visibility to upper airway structures such as the nasal passages, pharynx, or larynx. Instead, tools like laryngoscopes or endoscopes are employed for this purpose.

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumor is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone

 

  • Pott's puffy tumor is the subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.
  • Pott puffy tumor is a soft doughy forehead swelling due to frontal bone osteomyelitis with associated subperiosteal abscess. PPT is a rare complication of frontal sinusitis, but can also occur due to trauma.
  • It is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.
  • The pathophysiology for the development of frontal skull osteomyelitis can occur due to hematogenous spread of the infection or to direct extension of infection.
  • Presents with tender forehead swelling associated with fever, headaches, nasal discharge, or symptoms of increased intracranial pressure
  • Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, it requires removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap through a coronal incision

 

 

Complications of frontal sinusitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subperiosteal abscess of ethmoid bone: Incorrect, as the ethmoid bone typically presents with other orbital or intranasal complications.

 

Option C. Mucocele of frontal bone: Incorrect, as mucoceles refer to mucus-filled cysts resulting from blocked sinus ducts, not infections.

 

Option D. Mucocele of ethmoid bone: Also incorrect and refers to a different pathological condition involving the ethmoid sinus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pott's puffy tumor is a severe and rare complication of frontal sinusitis, presenting with distinctive forehead swelling and potentially grave complications. Prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment are crucial to prevent further spread of infection and ensure recovery.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 224

questions.text: A patient presents with foul-smell from nose and nasal obstruction. The image of the finding is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atrophic rhinitis

 

Based on the image showing a significant amount of crusting and given the symptom of foul smell, the most likely diagnosis is Option A, Atrophic rhinitis.

 

Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by a thickening and drying out of the mucous membrane in the nose, leading to crusting, a widened nasal cavity, and a foul smell. The image showing thick, greenish crusts is consistent with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinitis sicca: Is associated with dryness of the nasal mucosa but without the severe crusting or foul smell typically seen in atrophic rhinitis. It usually does not present with the extent of crusting or debris depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Rhinosporidiosis: Is a chronic infection caused by the organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It typically presents with polyp-like masses in the nasal passage, which may be friable and bleed easily. The image does not clearly show polyp-like structures, which would be more indicative of this condition.

 

Option D. Allergic rhinitis: Is an allergic response causing symptoms like sneezing, itching, and a runny nose, often related to seasonal allergens. It does not cause the thick crusting or the foul smell evident in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of Atrophic Rhinitis is crucial, especially the distinctive symptoms of nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge, along with visible crusting as seen in the provided image. This helps differentiate it from other forms of rhinitis, which do not present with such severe crusting or malodour.

questions.text: Identify the air cell marked with red arrow in the CT scan of the nose and paranasal sinus: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulla Ethmoidalis

 

The red arrow in the CT scan points to a large air cell within the ethmoid sinus, which is the Bulla Ethmoidalis. The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus. It is centrally located within the ethmoid labyrinth and serves as a key landmark in endoscopic sinus surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Agger Nasi Cell: The Agger Nasi cell is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell, situated anteriorly and superiorly to the insertion of the middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Haller Cell: Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit. They are located inferiorly, near the orbit floor.

 

 

Option D. Onodi Cell: The Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends into the sphenoid bone and is situated near the optic nerve.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bulla Ethmoidalis is the largest and most constant air cell in the anterior ethmoid sinus.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JNA

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. The typical presentation includes nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis (nosebleeds).

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allergic Rhinitis: Nasal obstruction but no recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Coagulation Disorder: Bleeding from multiple sites, not specific to nasal obstruction in adolescent males.

 

Option D. Antrochoanal Polyp: Nasal obstruction without recurrent epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis, as it commonly presents in adolescent males with these symptoms.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. On examination, a pseudo membrane was noted over the tonsils which bleed on trying to remove and a bull-neck appearance of the neck. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Diphtheria

 

Based on the provided clinical history, the presence of a pseudo membrane and a bull-neck appearance strongly suggests a diagnosis of diphtheria. The diphtheritic membrane is firmly attached and may bleed when removed.

 

Causative organism – Corynebacterium diphtheriae

 

 

CLINICAL FEATURES

  • Children are affected more often
  • Oropharynx is commonly involved and the larynx and nasal cavity may also be affected.
  • In the oropharynx, a greyish white membrane forms over the tonsils and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. It is quite tenacious and causes bleeding when removed.
  • Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a “bull-neck” appearance. Patient is ill and toxemic but fever seldom rises above 38 °C.

 

COMPLICATIONS

 

  • Exotoxin produced by C. diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes myocarditis, cardiac arrhythmias and acute circulatory failure.
  • Neurological complications usually appear a few weeks after infection and include paralysis of soft palate, diaphragm and ocular muscles.
  • In the larynx, diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction.

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Dose of antitoxin is based on the site involved and the duration and severity of disease. It is 20,000–40,000 units for diphtheria in less than 48 h, or when the membrane is confined to the tonsils only; and 80,000–120,000 units, if disease has lasted longer than 48 h, or the membrane is more extensive.
  • Antibiotics used are benzyl penicillin 600 mg 6 hourly for 7 days. Erythromycin is used in penicillin-sensitive individuals (500 mg 6 hourly orally).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infectious Mononucleosis: Typically presents with fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes, but lacks the pseudo membrane and bull-neck appearance.

 

Option B. Tonsillitis: Inflammation of the tonsils, usually without the severe systemic symptoms seen in diphtheria.

 

Option D. Candidiasis: Can cause white patches in the mouth and throat but these are easily wiped away and not associated with systemic toxicity or the bull-neck appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria is a serious bacterial infection that requires immediate medical attention and treatment. The presence of a bleeding pseudo membrane and severe neck swelling in an unimmunized child is highly indicative of this condition, emphasizing the importance of vaccination and early intervention.

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trotter’s method

 

The image shows Trotter's method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epley's maneuver: Is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo).

 

 

Option C. Mc Govern technique: A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway. It is used as an emergency management may be required in bilateral choanal atresia to provide an airway.

 

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: A technique where the patient forcefully exhales while keeping the mouth and nose closed. This increases intrathoracic pressure and is used in various medical situations, including adjusting ear pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trotter’s method is an effective first-line intervention for controlling epistaxis. It emphasizes maintaining an upright, forward-leaning posture to minimize blood swallowing and facilitate proper drainage, essential for patient comfort and safety during a nosebleed episode.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No.  183, 199

questions.text: A 60-year-old individual with diabetes presented with intense ear pain and otorrhea that did not improve with antibiotics. During the examination, granulation tissue was observed in the external auditory canal (EAC), and the person also exhibited facial nerve palsy. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant otitis externa

 

Severe otalgia in an elderly diabetic patient with granulation tissue in the external ear canal points to a diagnosis of Malignant (Necrotizing) otitis externa.

 

ETIOLOGY – More common in elderly, diabetic and immunocompromised patients.

 

CAUSATIVE ORGANISM - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most common), Staphylococcus aureus, Proteus species, and fungi.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES

 

  • Excruciating ear pain
  • Granulations in the ear canal
  • Facial paralysis is common.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple lower cranial nerve palsies
  • Anteriorly, infection spreads to temporomandibular fossa
  • Posteriorly to the mastoid and medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

 

DIAGNOSIS

 

  • Gallium-67 is more useful in diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells, and is indicative of soft tissue infection. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment.          
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Control of diabetes
  • Aural toilet
  • Antibiotic treatment against causative organism, which in most commonly P. aeruginosa (or any other causative organism) for 6-8 weeks.
  • Antibiotics commonly used are anti-pseudomonal antibiotics ; Third-generation cephalosporins ; Ciprofloxacin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otomycosis: Typically presents with itching and a fungal ear discharge, without the severe pain or systemic complications seen in MOE.

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear, generally without the severe external ear pain or granulation tissue.

 

Option D. Eczematous otitis externa: Characterized by itching and skin changes, but not the deep infection or severe complications associated with MOE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant otitis externa is a critical condition requiring aggressive management due to its potential to cause widespread damage and severe complications, including cranial nerve involvement. Prompt and appropriate treatment is essential to prevent potentially life-threatening outcomes.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 55

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge along with the following CT scan. On suction cleaning, there is thick mucin that contains eosinophils, Charcot-Leyden crystals. What would be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Allergic fungal sinusitis

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge. The presence of thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, as well as the CT findings, are indicative of allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS). AFS is characterized by the accumulation of eosinophils and allergic mucin in the sinuses, often resulting in hyperdensities on CT scans.

 

Treatment is always surgical exploration (removal of fungal mass)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal Ball: A fungal ball, or mycetoma, typically involves a single sinus (commonly the maxillary sinus) and appears as a mass of fungal elements without significant allergic mucin or eosinophils. It does not usually present with eosinophils or Charcot-Leyden crystals in the discharge.

 

Option C. Chronic rhinosinusitis: Chronic rhinosinusitis involves prolonged inflammation of the sinuses but does not specifically present with the eosinophilic mucin and Charcot-Leyden crystals seen in AFS. The CT findings in chronic rhinosinusitis do not typically show the hyperdensities seen in AFS.

 

Option D. Fulminant fungal sinusitis: Fulminant fungal sinusitis is a rapidly progressive infection seen in immunocompromised patients and involves extensive bony destruction and tissue invasion. The CT scan would show significant bone destruction and possibly extension into adjacent structures, which is not evident in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic fungal sinusitis is characterized by unilateral nasal obstruction, thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, and hyperdensities on CT scans, without extensive bony destruction.

questions.text: Following sign is seen in (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

Explanation: 


The image shows the Holman-Miller sign (or antral sign), which is pathognomonic of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This sign is characterized by:

 

  • Forward bowing/anterior displacement of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  • Occurs due to tumor extension from sphenopalatine foramen into pterygopalatine fossa
  • The tumor exerts pressure from behind, pushing the posterior maxillary wall forward
  • This finding is visible on CT scan and is a key diagnostic feature of JNA

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

  • Shows Trotter's triad (palatal palsy, ipsilateral neuralgia, conductive hearing loss)
  • No characteristic anterior bowing of posterior maxillary wall
  • Most commonly arises from fossa of Rosenmuller

 

Option C. Tear drop sign

 

  • Also called hanging drop sign
  • Seen in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures)
  • Not related to maxillary wall displacement

 

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis

 

  • Shows strawberry-like lesions in nasal cavity
  • Presents with epistaxis
  • No characteristic changes in maxillary sinus wall

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

questions.text: Investigation of choice for JNA? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CECT

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular tumor found in adolescent males. The investigation of choice for JNA is Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT). CECT is preferred because it effectively delineates the bony margins and the extent of the tumor, including any bone erosion. The contrast enhancement helps in identifying the vascular nature of the tumor, which is crucial in differentiating JNA from other masses in the nasal cavity, such as adenoids or carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI: MRI is helpful for assessing orbital and cranial extensions of the tumor but is not the primary choice for initial diagnosis. It does not provide as clear an image of the bony structures as CECT does.

 

Option C. DNE (Diagnostic Nasal Endoscopy): While DNE can visualize a mass in the nasal cavity, it cannot determine the type of mass or its vascular nature. It is less informative than imaging studies in the diagnosis of JNA.

 

Option D. Biopsy: Biopsy is contraindicated in suspected JNA due to the high risk of severe bleeding given the vascular nature of the tumor. Attempting a biopsy can lead to significant complications.

 

Educational Objective:


The investigation of choice for diagnosing Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is CECT due to its ability to define the tumor's vascularity and extent while safely avoiding the complications associated with biopsy

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a positive Hitzelberger sign. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vestibular schwannoma

 

Explanation:

 

A positive Hitzelberger sign indicates hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in the external auditory canal. This sign is pathognomonic for acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma). Hitzelberger sign occurs when the nervus intermedius (sensory branch of facial nerve) is compressed in the internal auditory canal by the growing tumor. It is considered the first sign that indicates facial nerve involvement in acoustic neuroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mastoiditis: This is an infection of the mastoid air cells that presents with postauricular pain, tenderness, and swelling. Signs include "ironing of mastoid surface" (smooth & shiny look), mastoid tenderness, and sagging of the posterior meatal wall. Hitzelberger sign is not associated with mastoiditis.

 

Option C. Bell's palsy: This is an idiopathic facial paralysis presenting with unilateral facial weakness. While it affects the facial nerve, Bell's palsy doesn't typically cause hypoesthesia of the posterior canal wall. Bell's palsy affects the motor component of the facial nerve, not the sensory fibers that would produce Hitzelberger sign.

 

Option D. Middle ear cholesteatoma: This is "skin in the wrong place" - keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear. It can cause ossicular destruction and various complications, but Hitzelberger sign is not one of them. Cholesteatoma affects the middle ear structures, not the internal auditory canal where compression causing Hitzelberger sign occurs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hitzelberger sign (decreased sensation in the posterior meatal wall) is pathognomonic for vestibular schwannoma and represents early involvement of the facial nerve as the tumor compresses the nervus intermedius in the internal auditory canal.

questions.text:
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?

(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
✅ Correct Answer: B. Grade 2

📸 Image Analysis:

The otoscopic image shows a retracted pars tensa where deeper middle ear structures like the long process of the incus and incudostapedial joint are visible. The lateral process of the malleus is prominently seen, and the tympanic membrane appears pulled medially, but it is not adherent to the promontory, and air is still visible in the middle ear. This presentation is typical of Grade 2 retraction.

🔍 Explanation of Options:

Option A: Grade 1

In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.

 

Option B: Grade 2

Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.

 

Option C: Grade 3

In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.

 

Option D: Grade 4

This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

🧠 Educational Objective:

Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

questions.text: Which of the following has the worst prognosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Partial Bilateral Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) Palsy

Explanation for Correct Answer:

Partial Bilateral RLN palsy involves selective paralysis of only the abductor fibers (as per Semon’s Law), while the adductor fibers remain intact. This results in both vocal cords being pulled medially into the median position, due to the unopposed action of the intact adductors and the cricothyroid muscle (innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).

In this median position, the glottic airway is severely compromised, leading to inspiratory stridor, dyspnea, and often acute airway obstruction, despite the voice being relatively preserved.

This situation is life-threatening and usually requires an emergency tracheostomy, making it the worst prognosis among all types.

Explanation for Other Options:

A. Partial Unilateral RLN Palsy

  • Only abductor fibers are affected on one side.
  • The affected vocal cord moves to median position, but the contralateral healthy cord compensates.
  • Voice may be mildly hoarse, but airway is adequate.
  • Good prognosis.

C. Complete Unilateral RLN Palsy

  • Both abductor and adductor fibers are lost on one side.
  • Cord lies in paramedian position (due to passive pull of cricothyroid).
  • Other side compensates for both voice and airway.
  • Moderate prognosis.

D. Complete Bilateral RLN Palsy

  • Both cords lie in paramedian position (both abduction and adduction lost).
  • Airway is compromised but slightly better than in partial bilateral palsy.
  • Often needs tracheostomy, but not as acute as partial bilateral.
  • Serious but not worst prognosis

Semon’s Law:

In progressive organic lesions of the RLN, abductor fibers (posterior cricoarytenoid) are more vulnerable and affected first, while adductor fibers are more resistant. Hence, early (partial) palsy affects only abduction, leading to dangerous median cord positioning.

Comparison Table:

Educational Objective:

Partial bilateral RLN palsy carries the worst prognosis due to medial cord positioning from intact adductors and SLN action, causing life-threatening airway obstruction despite relatively preserved voice.

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who is concerned about his nasal-sounding voice. She reports that her son seems to be frequently "talking through his nose," especially when he is trying to pronounce 'm' and 'n' sounds. Additionally, she mentions that he breathes through his mouth most of the time, especially at night, and has been having difficulty sleeping. On examination, the boy has no signs of acute respiratory distress but does have a hyponasal voice. Xray reveals enlarged adenoids obstructing the nasopharynx. No other abnormalities are noted. What type of voice change is most likely present in this patient due to his enlarged adenoids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinorrhea clausa

 

Given the context of adenoid enlargement affecting the voice, the most likely associated voice change would be Option A, Rhinolalia clausa, because enlarged adenoids can block the nasal passages and affect the normal resonance of speech.

 

Rhinolalia clausa is characterized by a nasal quality to the voice due to blockage in the nasal passages, which could be caused by enlarged adenoids. This blockage prevents normal resonance in the nasal cavities, leading to a muffled, nasal-sounding voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhinolalia aperta refers to a voice that sounds excessively nasal due to inadequate closure of the velopharyngeal sphincter, usually not directly associated with adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. A hot potato voice is typically described as a muffled and garbled voice, as if speaking with a hot potato in the mouth. This is often found in conditions such as a peritonsillar abscess rather than adenoid enlargement.

 

Option D. Echolalia is the repetition of phrases or sounds and is a communication disorder. It is not a type of voice quality and is not related to adenoids or their enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The voice of a patient with enlarged adenoids is likely to exhibit Rhinolalia clausa, characterized by a nasal quality due to obstruction of the nasal passages.

questions.text: What is absent in a case of otitis media among the options provided? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Battle's sign

 

Battle's sign, characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, is typically indicative of a basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving the temporal bone. It is not associated with otitis media, which is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: This abscess is a serious complication of otitis media. It occurs when the infection spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus.

Option B. Griesinger's sign: This sign is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis, a rare but severe complication of otitis media and mastoiditis. It involves tenderness and swelling behind the ear and along the mastoid bone.

Option D. Delta sign: Also related to lateral sinus thrombosis, the Delta sign typically appears on contrast-enhanced imaging studies as a NON enhancement at thrombosed area of sinus, a complication arising from otitis media.

Educational Objective:

 

While otitis media can lead to various complications, including Bezold abscess and lateral sinus thrombosis (indicated by Griesinger’s sign and Delta sign), Battle's sign is not associated with this condition. Instead, Battle's sign should prompt an evaluation for temporal bone fractures, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between signs of infection and trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for assessing non-organic hearing loss? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fowler Test

 

Explanation:

 

Fowler Test (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance Test) is not used for diagnosing non-organic hearing loss. It is specifically designed to detect and measure recruitment in unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. In this test, tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented alternately to both ears, and the patient is asked to compare loudness. The test helps identify cochlear pathology by demonstrating recruitment phenomenon, where sounds that are barely audible reach uncomfortable loudness with small increases in intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stenger's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss, particularly unilateral feigned hearing loss. It employs the principle that when tones of different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, only the louder tone is perceived. If a patient with claimed unilateral deafness denies hearing a tone presented to both ears (with the "deaf" ear receiving a stronger stimulus), malingering is confirmed.

 

Option C. Lombard's Test: This is correctly used to detect non-organic hearing loss. It relies on the principle that people unconsciously raise their voice when they cannot hear themselves speak. In this test, the patient is asked to read aloud while noise is introduced to their ears. A genuine hearing-impaired person will raise their voice, while a malingerer maintaining normal voice level reveals non-organic hearing loss.

 

Option D. Erhardt's Test: This is correctly used for detecting non-organic hearing loss. It employs tuning forks that appear identical but vibrate at different frequencies. The patient is shown which fork corresponds to which tone but cannot actually see which fork is being used in testing. Inconsistent responses reveal the non-organic nature of the hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Fowler Test (ABLB) is designed specifically to detect recruitment in sensorineural hearing loss, particularly of cochlear origin, and is not part of the standard test battery for identifying non-organic hearing loss or malingering.

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heimlich’s maneuver

 

The image shows a Heimlich's maneuver

 

First aid for foreign body in the airway -

 

A large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.

 

The first aid measures consist of pounding on the back, turning the patient upside down and following Heimlich maneuver. These measures should not be done if the patient is only partially obstructed, for fear of causing total obstruction.

 

Heimlich maneuver. - Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Back Slaps: Before attempting the Heimlich maneuver, delivering five firm back slaps between the individual's shoulder blades can be tried as this may dislodge the item.

 

Option C. Chest Thrusts: Used instead of abdominal thrusts in cases where the Heimlich might be risky, such as in very obese or pregnant individuals.

 

Option D. Blind Finger Sweeps: Not recommended due to the risk of pushing the object deeper into the throat, potentially worsening the blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Heimlich maneuver is an effective emergency procedure for saving lives in cases of severe choking. It is important for everyone to learn this technique as it can be performed on others or even on oneself in a choking emergency.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 367

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Battle sign

 

The image shows Battle's sign.

 

It is retroarticular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

 

Option C: Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness, swelling which is painful.

 

Option D: The Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Battle's sign is a significant diagnostic clue in trauma patients, signaling a possible basilar skull fracture. Recognition of this sign should prompt further diagnostic imaging and careful neurologic assessment to manage potential complications associated with such fractures.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition

questions.text: The following instrument is used for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringotomy

 

Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Myringotomy is most commonly done for serous otitis media in the anteroinferior quadrant radially. Sometimes, grommet insertion is done through the opening made by myringotome in the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septoplasty: This procedure corrects a deviated nasal septum, involving different instruments primarily for reshaping the nasal structure, not for ear-related surgeries.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a procedure to repair a perforation of the tympanic membrane but does not typically use a myringotome; instead, it uses tools for patching or grafting the membrane.

 

Option D. Adenoidectomy: This surgery involves the removal of the adenoids located in the upper part of the throat behind the nose, using different instruments like curettes or microdebriders, not a myringotome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The myringotome is crucial for performing a myringotomy, allowing for precise incisions in the tympanic membrane to address issues such as serous otitis media. The instrument's design facilitates targeted, clean cuts to insert grommets if needed.

choices.text: Cochlear implants lead to improved speech and sound perception.
Cochlear implants offer a better chance of acquiring normal or near-normal verbal skills.
Cochlear implants improve sound localization and discrimination.
Cochlear implants increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cochlear implants is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cochlear implants increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation.

 

Explanation:


Cochlear implants do not increase tinnitus in patients who had tinnitus before implantation. In fact, the opposite is true - cochlear implants often help reduce tinnitus in most patients who experience it prior to implantation. The electrical stimulation provided by the implant can mask or suppress the tinnitus sensation. Studies show that cochlear implantation can reduce or even eliminate pre-existing tinnitus in approximately 70-80% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear implants lead to improved speech and sound perception: This statement is true. Cochlear implants bypass damaged hair cells in the cochlea and directly stimulate the auditory nerve, allowing for improved detection and discrimination of sounds. This leads to enhanced speech perception and better understanding of environmental sounds.

 

Option B. Cochlear implants offer a better chance of acquiring normal or near-normal verbal skills: This statement is true, especially for children who receive implants early. Early implantation (before 6 years of age in pre-lingual deaf children) allows for better development of auditory pathways and improved chances of developing age-appropriate speech and language skills.

 

Option C. Cochlear implants improve sound localization and discrimination: This statement is true. Cochlear implants help improve sound discrimination abilities, allowing recipients to better distinguish between different sounds. Bilateral implantation particularly improves sound localization abilities by providing binaural cues necessary for spatial hearing.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Contrary to increasing tinnitus, cochlear implants typically reduce or suppress pre-existing tinnitus in most patients due to the masking effect of electrical stimulation and reorganization of central auditory pathways following implantation.

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the marked structure? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess

 

The identified anatomical feature corresponds to the sphenoid sinus, which effectively empties into the Sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior meatus: This meatus drains the posterior ethmoid sinus.

 

Option B. Middle meatus: The middle meatus is the drainage site for several other sinuses, including the frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoid sinus. It is the most common drainage site for these sinuses, but not for the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option C. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, which is responsible for draining tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. It does not play a role in draining any of the paranasal sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 209

questions.text: Identify the PTA. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixed

 

The audiogram shows characteristics of mixed hearing loss where both conductive and sensorineural components are present:

 

  • There is an air-bone gap (separation between air and bone conduction curves) indicating a conductive component
  • The bone conduction curve is below normal (>25 dB) indicating sensorineural component
  • The air conduction shows even greater hearing loss (50-70 dB)
  • Both curves are below normal range but maintain a gap between them

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHL (Conductive Hearing Loss): In pure conductive hearing loss, bone conduction would be normal (within 25 dB) with only air conduction being affected, creating an air-bone gap. Here bone conduction is also affected.

 

Option B. SNHL (Sensorineural Hearing Loss): In pure SNHL, both air and bone conduction curves would be affected but would be close together without significant gap. Here there is a clear air-bone gap.

 

Option D. None: The audiogram clearly shows pathological findings and cannot be considered normal where both curves would be within 25 dB with no gap.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mixed hearing loss, the audiogram shows both bone conduction below normal (SNHL component) and an air-bone gap (conductive component), indicating pathology in both inner ear and middle/outer ear.

 

  • Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap(AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap) or not
  • If there is no air-bone gap or very little gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see whether the distantly separated curves are present in the upper part of the graph or lower part.
  • If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

 

A positive fungal culture is a minor diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

This classification was detailed by Bent and Kuhn, who established criteria based on their findings of several clinical features important for the diagnosis of AFRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of nasal polyps: Polyps are a common and significant finding in AFRS, often contributing to the blockage and symptoms of sinusitis.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic mucin: A hallmark of AFRS, this refers to thick, peanut butter-like mucin with eosinophils.

 

Option C. Characteristic CT findings: These include hyperdense areas within the sinuses, which are indicative of fungal involvement and mucin accumulation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: Water's view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

Waters’ view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position). The X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.

 

In this view, petrous bones are projected below the maxillary antra.

 

Structures seen are:

 

  1. Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  2. Frontal sinuses
  3. Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth).
  4. Zygoma
  5. Zygomatic arch
  6. Nasal bone.
  7. Frontal process of maxilla
  8. Superior orbital fissure
  9. Intratemporal fossa.

 

Other 3 Options: Not best visualized in Water's view as this technique primarily highlights the maxillary and other larger sinuses.
 

Educational Objective:
 

Water's view is particularly effective for visualizing the maxillary sinus, making it an essential diagnostic tool in sinus imaging, especially when evaluating issues related to the maxillary sinuses.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: A male cattle breeder from South India presents with frank, intermittent epistaxis. The description of the nasal examination is provided below. A biopsy was conducted, and the histopathological examination findings are depicted as presented below. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

The given clinical scenario, image showing a patient with polypoidal mass and HPE image revealing sporangium, points to a diagnosis of Rhinosporidiosis.

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)

  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.

  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas

  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.

  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness

  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)

  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

Other Options:

Option A. Nasal polyp: Typically presents as a non-neoplastic mass, usually bilateral and associated with conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis. They do not bleed on touch and do not have the characteristic histopathological findings seen in Rhinosporidiosis.

Option C. Hemangioma: Vascular tumors that appear as reddish-blue lesions, which are compressible and usually do not present with the same histopathological features as Rhinosporidiosis.

Option D. Rhinophyma: A severe form of rosacea resulting in a large, bulbous, and red nose. It is not associated with nasal bleeding or the histopathological findings presented in this case.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients presenting with polypoidal nasal masses, especially if there is a history of exposure to contaminated water. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy revealing characteristic sporangia, and treatment involves surgical excision with cauterization.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

 

ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 

Pathology - Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous type. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterative endarteritis. The bone of turbinates undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers. Paranasal sinuses are small due to their arrested development.

 

Clinical Features

 

  1. Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty
  2. Foul smell from the nose though the patient himself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
  3. Patients may complain of nasal obstruction due to large crusts filling the nose.
  4. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

 

On examination shows

 

  1. Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or grayish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  2. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.
  3. Nasal mucosa appears pale. Septal perforation and dermatitis of nasal vestibule may be present. Nose may show a saddle deformity.
  4.  Atrophic changes may also be seen in the pharyngeal mucosa larynx.
  5. Hearing impairment may be noticed because of obstruction to the eustachian tube and middle ear effusion.
  6. Paranasal sinuses are usually small and underdeveloped with thick walls.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

 

Surgical management:

 

  • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyps: These are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: It is associated with various mucosal diseases which include allergic rhinitis, infectious rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: It is commonly seen in children and the child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given endoscopic view of the nasal cavity:(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

 

Marked structure is Inferior turbinate.

 

  • Inferior turbinate is a separate bone, arranged longitudinally.
  • Attaches anteriorly with maxilla and posteriorly with palatine bone.
  • Also attached to lacrimal bone and uncinate process of ethmoid in between.
  • Over the bone, thick vascular mucosal tissue surrounds.
