  • The vascular channels travel from posterior to anterior inside the turbinate mucosa, so that inspired air will be in exchange of moisture (humidification of inspired air) with vascular channels for a long duration.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Middle turbinate: This is located above the inferior turbinate and is part of the ethmoid bone. It plays a role in directing air flow and protecting sinus openings.

 

Option C. Superior turbinate: The smallest of the turbinates, located higher up in the nasal cavity and also part of the ethmoid bone.

 

Option D. Uncinate process: This is a part of the ethmoid bone that forms the anterior border of the hiatus semilunaris, involved in the drainage pathway of the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior turbinate is a critical structure for the proper conditioning of air entering the respiratory system. Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: Primarily involves destructive lesions of the midline facial structures but lacks the fungal component.

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Typically arises from a reaction to a foreign material but would not cause the extensive symptoms or be positive on the fungal stains used.

 

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: Associated with elevated levels of IgG4 and typically presents with tumefactive lesions, not primarily infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on pinching the nostrils. Nasal packing was done but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation should be considered in cases where epistaxis is not controlled by trotters method or nasal packing.

 

Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point.

 

Most common artery to be ligated for epistaxis is Sphenopalatine artery followed by internal maxillary artery, External carotid artery, Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligation of external carotid artery: The external carotid artery is a major artery that supplies blood to numerous facial structures, including the scalp, face, jaw, and more. Ligation of this artery is generally considered a more drastic measure and is typically reserved for severe cases where other specific arterial sources of bleeding have been ruled out or are inaccessible. It is much less selective than targeting the sphenopalatine artery and can lead to significant complications due to reduced blood flow to essential tissues.

 

Option B. Ligation of internal carotid artery: This option is generally not considered for epistaxis management due to the critical nature of the internal carotid artery, which primarily supplies blood to the brain. Ligation of this artery would pose a high risk of serious neurological deficits or stroke. It is a major artery and not a contributor to nasal bleeding; thus, it is not targeted in the treatment of epistaxis.

 

Option D. Ligation of maxillary artery: The maxillary artery is a major artery within the face that branches off the external carotid artery and gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery. While ligation of the maxillary artery is an option for severe epistaxis, it is less specific than targeting the sphenopalatine artery. The maxillary artery supplies areas broader than just the nasal cavity, including the maxilla, mandible, teeth, and parts of the face. Therefore, ligation of this artery is considered more invasive and has a higher risk of complications compared to the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a highly effective surgical procedure for controlling severe or refractory epistaxis after more conservative measures have failed. This approach targets a primary blood supply to the nasal cavity, significantly reducing the risk of further bleeding.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male is brought to OPD with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, a mass was observed on left posterior choanae as shown below. What is the management of the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Surgical excision

 

Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgical excision will be the management of the patient.

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

  • Most common benign tumor of nasopharynx.
  • Site of origin: sphenopalatine foramen.
  • It is highly vascular tumor. vessels are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for the severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract; also, the bleeding cannot be controlled by application of adrenaline, hence biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Extensions of JNA

 

  1. Nasal cavity causing nasal obstruction, epistaxis and nasal discharge.
  2. Paranasal sinuses. Maxillary, sphenoid and ethmoid sinuses can all be invaded.
  3. Pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa and cheek.
  4. Orbits giving rise to proptosis and “frog-face deformity.” It enters through the inferior orbital fissure and also destroys apex of the orbit. It can also enter the orbit through superior orbital fissure.
  5. Cranial cavity. It can extend into:
  6. Anterior cranial fossa through roof of ethmoids or cribriform plate.
  7. Middle cranial fossa through erosion of floor of middle cranial fossa or indirectly by invading the sphenoid sinus and Sella turcica. In the former case, tumor lies lateral to internal carotid artery and in the latter case medial to the artery

 

Clinical features –

 

  • Adolescent male
  • Profuse spontaneous recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction with denasal speech
  • Conductive hearing loss due to tubal block
  • Pink/purple mass in the nasopharynx
  • Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumor.

 

Investigation:

 

  1. CECT (contrast enhanced CT) - This shows Hollman miller sign or antral sign i.e., anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  2. MRI is complementary to CT scan
  3. Angiography – to assess blood supply of tumor. Feeding vessels should be embolized preoperatively

 

Treatment – Surgical excision is treatment of choice.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): Not suitable for JNA: Due to the tumor's high vascularity, FNAC could result in significant bleeding and is not typically used for diagnosis or treatment in cases suspected of being JNA.

 

Option B. Biopsy: Risk of severe bleeding: Similar to FNAC, a direct biopsy of JNA is contraindicated due to the risk of triggering severe hemorrhage from the tumor’s vascular structure.

 

Option C. Radiotherapy: Not a primary treatment: While radiotherapy can be considered in certain cases where surgical excision is incomplete or not feasible, it is not the primary treatment method for JNA. The primary approach is surgical removal, given the effectiveness of surgery in achieving control of the tumor and minimizing long-term complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected JNA, especially with the classical presentation of recurrent nosebleeds in adolescent males, prompt referral for imaging and surgical consultation is critical. Surgical excision, following detailed imaging and possibly preoperative embolization, represents the best approach to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: Infections of the middle ear can extend to the brain through all of the following routes, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spread through Lymphatic Channels

 

Explanation:

 

Middle ear infections do not spread to the brain through lymphatic channels because there are no lymphatic connections between the middle ear and intracranial structures. The brain and cranial cavity lack a traditional lymphatic system. Infection from the middle ear to the brain occurs through other routes including direct bone erosion, preformed pathways, or hematogenous spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Bony Invasion: This is a common route of intracranial spread of middle ear infection. Cholesteatoma or chronic infection can erode the tegmen tympani (roof of middle ear), allowing infection to spread to the middle cranial fossa causing extradural or subdural abscess. Similarly, erosion of the posterior wall can lead to cerebellar abscess.

 

Option B. Oval or Round Window: These are preformed pathways through which infection can spread from the middle ear to the inner ear (labyrinthitis), and then to the internal auditory canal and cerebellopontine angle through the cochlear aqueduct or internal auditory canal. The subarachnoid space can be accessed through the cochlear aqueduct, which connects the scala tympani with the subarachnoid space.

 

Option C. Spread via Bloodstream: Hematogenous spread is another valid route where infection spreads through venous channels, particularly through emissary veins or by thrombophlebitis of the sigmoid sinus. This can lead to lateral sinus thrombosis, meningitis, or brain abscess.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While middle ear infections can spread to intracranial structures through direct bone erosion, preformed pathways (oval/round windows), and bloodstream, there is no lymphatic route for such spread since the brain lacks traditional lymphatics.

questions.text: What is the sign shown below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Double target sign

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the double target sign (also called target sign, halo sign, or double ring sign) which is seen in CSF rhinorrhoea. It is characterized by:

 

  • A central red spot (blood)
  • Surrounded by a peripheral halo (CSF)
  • This pattern appears when CSF mixed with blood drips onto filter paper or cloth
  • Commonly seen in traumatic CSF rhinorrhoea where blood is mixed with cerebrospinal fluid

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tear drop sign

 

  • Also called hanging drop sign
  • Radiological finding seen in blow-out fractures of orbit
  • Not related to CSF rhinorrhea

 

 

Option C. Beta 2 transferrin sign

 

  • This is not a visual sign but a laboratory test
  • Used to confirm the presence of CSF in nasal discharge
  • Tests for beta 2 transferrin which is specific to CSF

 

Option D. Handkerchief sign

 

  • Test where nasal discharge is placed on handkerchief
  • CSF doesn't stiffen the handkerchief while mucus does
  • Used to differentiate CSF from nasal mucus

 

Educational Objective:

 

CSF Rhinorrhea
